comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: The girl on the right - it's about time she got her (or rather A.H. Poole's) racket restrung. Some of those strings are very loose.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] The 1911 Census shows James aged 35, Katie, 34 (Born in Kildare 1877ish) Mai 4, Joseph 3 and Kathleen 1 as the family in the house.  In addition Mary Osrant 20 and Bridie Osrant 13 are listed as household servants.  Morley Terrace was in the Gracedieu area of Waterford whose residents had notions about themselves. (Or so I told my in laws for many years!)

comment.author: 31176851@N02
comment._content: Sweet family  posing :)

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] I just realised that I did not comment on the shot itself.  It really is a lovely portrait and such pretty ladies - mother and daughters.  The chances are that Kathleen with the racquet was wearing Mai's hand-me-downs which might explain the ragged hem to the dress.  Both the younger girls socks are hanging loose which in those days probably meant no garters as elasticated tops were not the norm.  I wore elastic garters for my school socks way back when and they were great for firing papaer bullets at the teachers and other pupils. (and yes both boys and girls wore garters in those days!)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] There's definitely a thesis to be done on Poole Photographic Studio props from the 1880s to the 1940s... Suspect that the strings were loose from off scene bashing of the heads of hundreds of sisters and brothers over the years, before the perfect poses were adopted!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 83041814@N00
comment._content: Maybe it's my imagination, but it seems that a lot of photos you post were taken in Waterford. You may have already answered this, but I was just wondering why this might be?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/83041814@N00] Its simple really the people in Waterford are so photogenic that all the old photographs in Ireland came from there! A nice family named Poole who photographed all and sundry there donated their collection to the National Library and that is what is being displayed.  Some of them are very striking and the quality is exceptional!

comment.author: 58849627@N05
comment._content: lovely, the kids seem to have their mother's nose.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: A.H. poole was a prolific Waterford photographer and apparently the NLI has over 60,000 of his photos.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
Tis' not the hem of her skirt that is ragged, but a lace overlay hanging down.
She is showing her lace drawers in the style of the day, but they still do over here in Blackpool, Lancs.

comment.author: 75116182@N04
comment._content: Nice portrait of big family. I don't think  that the girl sitting at the right has her skirt frayed but I think she has a white shawl on her lap and all the girls have the same kind of socks.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/58849627@N05] Desperately trying to resist (and failing) the temptation of saying that noses ran in the Cunningham family!  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75116182@N04] Take both your points! You may well be right about the shawl/lace overlay hanging down. That's what I get for being pass remarkable about the poor child...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/thiskidgotmoxie] It is not at all your imagination. Every day I upload two photos, one of which was taken on that day and month at some time in the past. It just happens that we have especially accurate dates for the photos in our Poole Collection, and as that studio was based in Waterford, the bulk of their photos were taken in and around Waterford, but also in a wider area of the South-East of Ireland... It also doesn't hurt that as [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] points out, "the quality is exceptional"!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/14302637@N08] You're quite right, the threads hanging down are in fact parts of a crocheted shawl or overdress that young Kathleen is wearing.  I didn't spot that the two girls at the front were showing their knicker legs, I haven't looked under a young girls skirt since I was their age so I'm out of the habit!

comment.author: 42400804@N05
comment._content:
raggedy tomboy???

the mother's lace dress is, I think, exquisite

comment.author: 12099135@N05
comment._content: I look at this photo and think...all of these people must have passed away by now..except for the youngest one..she may still be alive.  This is a very good photo ..well perserved photo from that time.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] I have to say, it strikes me far more as being embroidery-style adornment, rather than lace, per se...

comment.author: 42400804@N05
comment._content: no, you're right, it's not lace at all - sorry for misleading you

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/42400804@N05] Not misleading at all! All contributions are welcome...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
Lace was not always openwork and could be quite like embroidery at times.  If you remember back to those fantastic lace vestments worn by some of the clergy, a lot of it was open work like crochet but some was backed up by material and more or less embroidered onto the surface.  Looking at that material there is a semi-print effect.  I must speak to my resident expert on such matters for her guidance.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/14302637@N08]  Good man, I hadn't heard of Guipure lace in donkeys years, it could also have been Limerick Lace which could be very sharp!!!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] As regards my previous weaknesses I managed to grow out of the habit before I got to the age where I might be arrested for it!  So all is well now!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Phew! Good to know...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Did you have a consultation with your "resident expert on such matters" yet?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] I spoke with the Resident expert and she agrees with your comment of 4 days ago that it is an embossing and embroidery type adornment/pattern on the material.  Guipure lace like Limerick Lace were much more open work and an item of such volume would have cost a fortune even in those days!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Please convey our thanks to your Resident Expert!  :)
